byline: By Claire Gatinois (Luanda (Angola) special correspondent) and Philippe Ricard (Geneva (Switzerland) special correspondent)
subhed: Negotiations in Geneva led to the removal of the most problematic points for European Union countries and Ukraine from the US plan. But the revised 19-point plan is yet to be finalized and must still be presented to the Russians.

Despite setbacks, Trump barrels onward with strategy of legal retribution
byline: By Nicolas Chapuis (New York (United States) correspondent)
subhed: The indictments against James Comey and Letitia James were thrown out on Monday, November 24, due to procedural errors. However, treason charges now loom over Senator Mark Kelly, who had called on military personnel not to follow illegal orders.

title: France bids farewell to popular pandas returning to China
subhed: As hundreds of visitors turned up to see Huan Huan and Yuan Zi before they boarded a plane to China on Tuesday, China announced new giant pandas will be sent to France.

title: Paris shops are squeezed by overtourism and real estate speculation
subhed: Between the needs of residents and the desire to attract tourists, commerces in the French capital have to strike a delicate balance. Failing to do so can be detrimental, as seen by the decline of the BHV department store.

title: France's cultural landmarks enter a time of costly makeovers
subhed: Lack of regular upkeep and the effects of climate change have forced many cultural institutions to undertake massive renovation projects, with costs expected to reach €5 billion over the next 10 years.

title: Flattery and humiliation: Europe's Trump diplomacy nightmare
byline: By Philippe Ricard and Claire Gatinois
subhed: To maintain a transatlantic relationship seen as essential, Europe has adapted to the US president's unpredictable demands, even at the risk of slipping into servility.

title: Niklas Frank, a son consumed by hatred for his Nazi father
subhed: Niklas Frank, an 86-year-old former journalist, is known in Germany for his absolute loathing of his father. As a Reich official, Hans Frank, appointed by Hitler in Poland, was among those sentenced to death at the Nuremberg trials, which began 80 years ago.
